The '''2017 [[Golden Globes (Portugal)]]''' was held on 21 May 2017 and broadcast by [[Sociedade Independente de Comunicação|SIC]] and presented by [[João Manzarra]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://caras.sapo.pt/globosdeouro|title=Globos de Ouro|website=Caras}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sic.sapo.pt/Programas/globosdeourosic/foto/2017-05-22-Globos-de-Ouro-2017-Os-vencedores|title=Globos de Ouro 2017: Os vencedores|publisher=}}</ref>

'''AKTA TV''' is a [[Romania]]n [[Direct To Home|DTH]] platform. It belongs to Digital Cable Systems, a [[telecommunication]] operator which offers [[satellite television|satellite]], [[cable television]], internet and telephony in over 2,500 locations in Romania.
It was launched in Romania in June 2005 under the name '''Max TV'''. From 2008, the official name is AKTA TV.
==Launch dates==
* 9 September 2005 - HBO and Cinemax become available in the AKTA TV package. * 9 March 2006 - Digital Cable System launches an offer for its new users. *18 February 2007 - Kanal D becomes available in the AKTA TV package. * 1 April 2007 - Romantica becomes available in the AKTA TV package. * 9 April 2007 - Antena 2 becomes available in the AKTA TV package. *13 April 2007 - HBO Comedy becomes available in the AKTA TV package.

The '''Afghan Women's Council (AWC)''' (also known as the ''Women's Council'') was an [[organization]] under the ''Democratic Republic of Afghanistan'' (1978-87) and the [[Republic of Afghanistan]] between (1987-1992). Until 1989 the leader of the organization was [[Masuma Esmati-Wardak]], Wardak was not a member of the [[People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan]] (PDPA) and in 1991 she became Minister of Education.<ref name="education">{{cite web|author=Mary Ann Tétreault |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X95R043HBJwC&pg=PA227&dq=Afghan+Women%27s+Council&lr=&hl=no |title=Women and revolution in Africa, Asia, and the New World |publisher=''Google Books'' | accessdate=2009-03-24}}</ref>
The organization was run by Wardak and a staff of eight women. Some of these staff members were also members of the PDPA. When the [[communist regime]] in 1978 under [[Nur Muhammad Taraki]] the government gave equal rights to women. Women now had the ability to choose their [[husband]]s, [[education]]-- they had the ability to make decisions about their own lives.<ref name="womencouncil">{{cite web|author=Lawrence Kaplan |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FBVCgetqZAAC&pg=PA139&dq=DRA+Afghan+Minister+of&lr=&hl=no#PPA144,M1 |title=Fundamentalism in comparative perspective |publisher=''Google Books'' | accessdate=2009-03-24}}</ref> The membership of the AWC was around 150,000 around the country and had branches and bases in all Afghan [[province]]s with the exception of [[Wardak Province|Wardak]] and [[Katawaz]]. Most of the women in [[Kabul]] resisted the [[Mujahideen]] because of their retrogressive laws concerning women.<ref name="education"/>
The AWC provided [[social service]]s to women in [[Afghanistan]], in the fight against [[illiteracy]] and [[vocational training]] for those in the [[Secretary]], [[hairdressing]] and [[workshop]] fields. Many feared the sacrificing of the AWC in the [[national reconciliation]] talks which started in 1987.<ref name="womencouncil"/>
One of the post important AWC programmes was their fight for the [[literacy]] and [[education]] of girls. According to AWC survey in 1991 estimated around 7 thousand women were in the institution of [[higher education]] and around 230,000 girls studying in [[school]]s around Afghanistan. According to the survey there existed around 190 female [[professors]] and 22,000 female [[teacher]]s in the country.<ref name="womencouncil"/>
== See also == * [[Women's rights in Afghanistan]]
== References == {{reflist}}

[[Image:Armoiries de Jérusalem.svg|thumb|right|125px|Coat of arms of the kingdom of Jerusalem.]]
The '''Assizes of Jerusalem''' are a collection of numerous medieval legal treatises written in [[Old French]] containing the law of the [[crusade]]r [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]] and [[Kingdom of Cyprus]]. They were compiled in the thirteenth century, and are the largest collection of surviving medieval laws.
==History==
As [[Peter Edbury]] says: "one group of sources from the Latin East that have long excited the attention of scholars are the [[legal treatise]]s often known collectively, if somewhat misleadingly, as the '''Assises of Jerusalem'''." (Peter W. Edbury, ''John of Ibelin and the Kingdom of Jerusalem'', pref.)
The [[assize]]s, or ''assises'' in [[French language|French]], survive in written form only from the 13th century, at least a generation after the collapse of the [[Kingdom of Jerusalem]]. The earliest laws of the Kingdom were promulgated at the [[Council of Nablus]] in 1120, but these laws seem to have fallen out of use and were replaced by the assizes by the 13th century and presumably even earlier.
Although no laws or court cases survive from the height of the kingdom in the 12th century, the kingdom obviously had laws and a well-developed legal structure. By the 13th century, the development of this structure was lost to memory, but jurists such as Philip and John recounted the legends that had grown up about the early kingdom. According to them, both the Haute Cour and the burgess court were established in 1099 by [[Godfrey of Bouillon]], who set himself up as judge of the high court. The laws of both were said to have been written down from the very beginning in 1099, and were simply lost when Jerusalem was captured by [[Saladin]] in 1187. These laws were kept in a chest in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, and were thus known in [[Old French language|Old French]] as the "''Letres dou Sepulcre''." The chest supposedly could have only been opened by the king, the [[Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem|Patriarch of Jerusalem]], and the [[Officers of the Kingdom of Jerusalem|viscount of Jerusalem]]. Each law, according to Philip, was written on one page, beginning with a large initial [[manuscript illumination|illuminated in gold]], and with a [[rubric]] written in red ink. Philip claimed to have obtained his information from an old knight and jurist named [[Ralph of Tiberias]], and John in turn probably got his information from Philip. Whether or not these legends were true (Edbury, for one, believes they were not), the 13th century jurists envisioned the legal structure of the kingdom to have existed continuously from the original conquest.
Some of the treatises are said to represent Western feudal law, as interpreted by baronial jurists to weaken royal power, but later scholarship argues that the works present an idealized legal model rather than proof of an existing feudal structure.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |editor-last=Kazkhdan |editor-first=Alexander P. |encyclopedia=The Oxford Dictionary of Byzantium | title=Jerusalem, Assizes of |year=2005 |publisher=Oxford |isbn=9780195046526}}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia |editor-last=Bkork |editor-first=Robert E. |encyclopedia=The Oxford Dictionary of the Middle Ages | title=Jerusalem, Assizes of (Livres des assises de Jérusalem) |year=2010|publisher=Oxford |isbn=9780198662624}}</ref>
==Texts==
The surviving collections of laws are:
*The ''Livre au Roi''. This is the earliest surviving text, dating from approximately 1200. It was written for [[Amalric II of Jerusalem]] (the "Roi" of the title) and has a decidedly royalist slant. It is the only text preserving the ''établissement'' of [[Baldwin II of Jerusalem|King Baldwin II]], which allowed the king to disinherit his [[vassal]]s, bypassing the normal judgement of the [[Haute Cour of Jerusalem|Haute Cour]]. Otherwise its contents are very similar to the other authors. *Le Livre de Forme de Plait. Philip of Novara's legal treatise, written from a more [[aristocracy|aristocratic]] viewpoint, was written in the 1250s. He also wrote a history of the conflict between the [[House of Ibelin|Ibelins]] (his patrons) and the [[Hohenstaufen]]s on [[Cyprus]] and in [[Akko|Acre]]. *[[John of Ibelin (jurist)|John of Ibelin]]. John, [[count of Jaffa and Ascalon]] and regent of the Kingdom of Jerusalem in Acre, was a participant in the struggle that Philip recorded elsewhere. From 1264 to 1266 he wrote the longest legal treatise from the Latin East, and indeed from anywhere in medieval Europe. *Geoffrey La Tor or Geoffrey le Tort, and James of Ibelin, John's son, independently wrote very small treatises, much less important than the larger works of Philip and John. *The ''Livre des Assises de la Cour des Bourgeois''. This is a lengthy work detailing the assizes the lower court of the kingdom, the burgess court, established for the non-noble class. Their author is anonymous, but they were also written in the mid-13th century. According to [[Joshua Prawer]] they derive from ''Lo Codi'', a [[Provence|Provençal]] law code itself based on [[Roman law]].
Also important on its own, although found in the ''Livre au Roi'', Philip, and John, is the ''[[Assise sur la ligece]]'', a law promulgated by [[Amalric I of Jerusalem]] in the 1170s, which effectively made every lord in the kingdom a direct vassal of the king and gave equal voting rights to [[vavasour|rear-vassals]] as much as the greater barons.
==Modern editions==
All of these works were edited in the mid- to late-19th century by [[Auguste Arthur, comte de Beugnot]], and published in the ''[[Recueil des Historiens des Croisades]]'' by the [[Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres]], in two volumes designated "''Lois''." Also included in the RHC are the 13th- and 14th-century ordinances of the [[Kingdom of Cyprus]]; a document concerning succession and regency, written by (or attributed to) [[John of Brienne]], [[king of Jerusalem]]; and a document concerning military service, written by (or attributed to) [[Hugh III of Cyprus]]. There are also a number of [[charter]]s, although a far more complete collection of charters was collected in the late 19th and early 20th century by [[Reinhold Röhricht]].
In the judgement of all later editors, from Maurice Grandclaude in the early 20th century to Edbury today, Beugnot was a very poor editor; fortunately, some, but not all, of these works have been edited separately. A French critical edition of the ''Livre au Roi'' was published by Myriam Greilshammer in 1995, and in 2003 Edbury published a critical edition of John of Ibelin's text. No new edition of the Old French assizes of the burgess court has been published since Beugnot's publication in 1843, but in the 15th century they were translated into [[Greek language|Greek]], and from the Greek manuscripts an English translation has recently been made by Nicholas Coureas.
Modern historians generally recognize the dangers in attributing 13th-century laws to the 12th-century kingdom, although earlier it was believed that these assizes represented the purest form of [[medieval]] European [[feudalism]]. In reality the laws probably reflect the practise of neither the 12th or the 13th century, as they were written from scratch in the 13th and were consciously designed to harken back to the less-troubled days of the 12th century, despite the important legal changes that had occurred in the meantime ([[trial by ordeal]], for example, was outlawed in the [[Fourth Lateran Council]] of 1215).
As mentioned above, it is somewhat misleading to call all of these texts the "Assizes of Jerusalem" as if they were written together at the same time; they often contradict one another or omit information that another text has. Together, however, they are the largest collection of laws written in a medieval European state for this period.
==Sources and further reading== *[[Auguste-Arthur, Comte de Beugnot|M. Le Comte Beugnot]], ed., ''Livre de Philippe de Navarre''. Recueil des Historiens des Croisades. Lois, tome premier. Paris: Académie Royal des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres, 1841. *M. Le Comte Beugnot, ed., ''Livre des Assises de la Cour des Bourgeois''. Recueil des Historiens des Croisades: Lois, tome deuxième. Paris: Académie Royal des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres, 1843. *Nicholas Coureas, trans., ''The Assizes of the Lusignan Kingdom of Cyprus''. Nicosia: Cyprus Research Centre, 2002. *Philip of Novara, ''Le Livre de forme de plait'', ed. and trans. [[Peter W. Edbury]]. Nicosia: Cyprus Research Centre, 2009. *John of Ibelin, ''Le Livre des Assises'', ed. [[Peter W. Edbury]]. Leiden: Brill, 2003. *Peter W. Edbury, "Law and Custom in the Latin East: Les Letres dou Sepulcre," ''[[Mediterranean Historical Review]]'' 10 (1995). *Peter W. Edbury, "Feudal Obligation in the Latin East," ''Byzantion'' 47 (1977). *Peter W. Edbury, ''John of Ibelin and the Kingdom of Jerusalem''. Woodbridge, Suffolk: The Boydell Press, 1997. *[[Maurice Grandclaude]], "Liste des assises remontant au premier royaume de Jérusalem (1099-1187)," in ''Mélanges Paul Fournier''. Paris: Société d'Histoire du Droit, 1929. *Myriam Greilsammer, ed., ''Le Livre au Roi''. Paris: Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres, 1995. *[[Joshua Prawer]], ''Crusader Institutions''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1980. *[[Reinhold Röhricht]], ed., ''Regesta Regni Hierosolymitani'' (MXCVII-MCCXCI), with ''Additamentum''. New York: 1893-1904.

revision.text:
'''''Dark Side of the Horse''''' ({{lang-fi|Musta hevonen}}, "the black horse") is a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[comic strip]], written and drawn by the comics artist [[Samuli Lintula]] under the pen name Samson. The strip features the horses Horace (''Heikki'', a steed) and Melody (''Helka'', a mare), and the bird Sine (''Sini''). In [[North America]], the strip is syndicated by the [[Royal Comics Syndicate]].<ref>[http://www.bullspress.fi/finland/Syndication/Products/Comics1/J-R/Musta-Hevonen/ Bullspress.fi]. Accessed on 18 July 2012.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://mustaheppa.sarjakuvablogit.com/ Official site] {{fi}} * [http://www.gocomics.com/darksideofthehorse Dark Side of the Horse at GoComics.com]

{{unreferenced|date=May 2018}}
The '''Franz Liszt Chamber Orchestra''' (''[[:hu:Liszt Ferenc Kamarazenekar|Liszt Ferenc Kamarazenekar]]'') is a [[chamber orchestra]] based in [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]].
The [[Franz Liszt]] Chamber Orchestra took the name of the great composer, to pay homage to the genius who became inseparable with the establishment of [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]] music and whose spirit irradiates the musical life of the entire world. After having studied for years at the [[Franz Liszt Academy]] in [[Budapest]], the Orchestra made its debut in 1963 and since then has played a very significant role in Hungarian and international musical life.
The Franz Liszt Chamber Orchestra consists of 17 strings, with the addition of other instruments as needed (harpsichord, winds, etc.)
==External links== *[http://www.lfkz.hu/ Franz Liszt Chamber Orchestra website]

[[Embakasi]], [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] |region_code = KE-100 |coordinates = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = Hon. James Wainaina Macharia[http://www.kcaa.or.ke/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=6&Itemid=2 Kenya Civil Aviation Authority – Directors] |minister1_pfo = Ministry of Transport,Infrastructure,Housing and Urban Development |chief1_name = Eng. Joseph Nakodony Nkadayo, MBS |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = Capt.Gilbert Macharia Kibe |chief2_position = Director General |agency_type = |keydocument1 = Kenya Civil Aviation Regulations (KCARS) 2013 |website = {{Url|www.kcaa.or.ke}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} '''Kenya Civil Aviation Authority''' ('''KCAA''') is a [[state corporation]] of [[Kenya]] that is responsible for regulating the [[aviation|aviation industry]] in Kenya and for providing [[air navigation|air navigation services]] in the Kenya flight region. The KCAA offers training in the aviation professions through its affiliated [[East African School of Aviation]].http://www.easa.ac.ke/ The agency maintains its headquarters in the Aviation Building at the junction entry to [[Jomo Kenyatta International Airport]] in [[Embakasi]], [[Nairobi]]."[http://www.kcaa.or.ke/index.php?option=com_frontpage&Itemid=1 Welcome to KCAA]." Kenya Civil Aviation Authority. Retrieved on 14 January 2011. "The Authority's head offices are currently situated at KAA Complex, JKIA in Nairobi.""[http://www.kcaa.or.ke/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=51&Itemid=48 Contact Us]." Kenya Civil Aviation Authority. Retrieved on 14 January 2011. "KCAA Headquarters KAA Complex, Jomo Kenyatta International Airport, Embakasi." ==History== The Civil Aviation (Amendment) Act, 2002 established the KCAA in 2002. The functions of the KCAA were previously performed by two departments of the [[Ministry of Transport (Kenya)|Ministry of Transport]]: the Civil Aviation Board (CAB) and the Directorate of Civil Aviation (DCA). == See also == {{Portal|Kenya|Aviation}} * [[Government of Kenya]] * [[Kenya Airports Authority]] * [[Civil aviation authority]] * [[List of civil aviation authorities]] == References == == External links == * [http://www.kcaa.or.ke/ Kenya Civil Aviation Authority] * [http://www.easa.ac.ke/ East African School of Aviation] {{Kenya Government Regulatory Bodies}} {{Aviation accident orgs}} [[Category:Government agencies of Kenya|Aviation]] [[Category:Aviation organisations based in Kenya]] [[Category:Civil aviation authorities in Africa|Kenya]] [[Category:Organisations based in Nairobi]] [[Category:Organizations investigating aviation accidents and incidents]] [[Category:Air navigation service providers]] [[Category:Civil aviation in Kenya]] {{Kenya-gov-stub}} {{Aviation-stub}}

[[Capital 95.8FM]] | webcast = {{unbulleted list | [http://mediacorp.rastream.com/972fm.m3u 48kb AAC+ stream] | [http://onlineradiobox.com/sg/love972/playlist/ Song List] }} | website = [http://radio.toggle.sg/en/radio/love-972-fm toggle.sg/love972] | callsign_meaning = }} '''LOVE 97.2FM''' (最爱频道 in [[Chinese language|Chinese]]) is a radio station of [[Mediacorp]] in [[Singapore]]. It is an adult contemporary music station, plays Mandarin , English and golden hits from the 1980s and 1990s interwoven with entertaining lifestyle capsules. Love 972 ended its broadcast at Caldecott Broadcast Centre on 3 February 2017 and then it was moved to Mediacorp Campus on 6 February 2017.The first programme broadcast there on that day was at 07:00 hrs. ==Staff== ===Management=== Programme Director: Karine Chua 蔡宜孜 (Previously from [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] as assistant manager) Promotions Manager: Lau Pei Wen (previously from [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]]) ===Full Time DJs=== [[File:Mediacorp Love 97.2FM DJs Bukoh Mary and Lina Tan, Bishan Junction 8, Apr 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Bukoh Mary (left) and Lina Tan hosting an outdoor event at Bishan Junction 8]] *Chen Bi Yu 陈碧玉 *[[Marcus Chin]] 陈建彬 *[[Dennis Chew]] 周崇庆(Previously from [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] and then joined this station in 2013) *[[Mark Lee (Singaporean actor)|Mark Lee]] 李国煌 *Violet Chen Fen Ying 陈粉樱 (Crossed over from [[883JiaFM]] in 1999) *Wendy Zeng Xiao Ying 曾晓英 (Previously Part Time DJ after she left as Full Time but came back in 2018) *Chua Li Lian 蔡礼莲 *Kenneth Kong 江坚文 (Previously from [[UFM 1003]] to [[Mediacorp Channel 8]] Current Affairs Programme Hello Singapore 《狮城有约》as a Presenter and joined this station in 2016) *Bukoh Mary 巫许玛莉 (Previously from [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] to [[Capital 95.8FM]] and joined this station in 2017) *Lina Tan 陈丽娜 (Previously from [[883JiaFM]] and joined this station in 2017) ===Part Time DJs=== *Ang Bee Choo 洪美珠 *Marvin 阶融 *Karin 燕洁 *Guo Xiu 国修 *Garrick Wong 王嘉翊 *Sharlyn Lim ===Former Notable DJs/Management who went to other Mediacorp Stations or Departments=== *Koh Bee Kwee 高美贵 (Previously Promo In Charge of this station but went to [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] as a DJ in 2017) *Jeff Goh (Joined this Station in 2008 crossed over to [[Y.E.S. 93.3 FM]] in 2013) ===Former Notable DJ/Management who have went to competitor stations=== *Jacky Liu Jie Qi 刘杰奇 (Previously Part Time DJ of [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] then joined this station in 2016 but left in the same year to [[96.3 Hao FM]]) *Ian Boon 温国贤 (Previously Senior Programme Director of [[Capital 95.8FM]] then joined this station as Part Time DJ but left in 2016 and in 2017 went to [[96.3 Hao FM]]) ===Former Notable DJs/Management who left the industry=== *Foong Wai See 冯慧诗 (Previously from [[Y.E.S. 93.3FM]] as a DJ then Senior Programme Director of this station but left in 2017) *Wallance Ang 洪圣安 (Previously Full Time DJ of this station) *Renee Yap 叶咏梅 (Previously Full Time DJ of this station) *Lan Huishan (joined Getai band Venus) == Weekday Time Belts == * 6 to 10am: 《早安！玉建煌崇》- 陈碧玉 (Chen Bi Yu) 、陈建彬 (Marcus Chin) 、李国煌 (Mark Lee) 和 周崇庆 (Dennis Chew) * 10am to 1pm: 《Love礼生活志》- 蔡礼莲 (Chua Li Lian) * 1pm to 4pm: 《最爱粉- Tastic》- 陈粉樱 (Violet Chen Fen Ying) * 4pm to 8pm: 《下班听英文》- 江坚文 (Kenneth Kong) 、曾晓英 (Wendy Zeng Xiao Ying) * 8pm to 11pm:《OH YAY！娜么美莉》 - 陈丽娜 (Lina Tan) 、巫许玛莉 (Bukoh Mary) == Shows produced == * [[The Love 97.2 Breakfast Quartet]] ==See also== *[[List of radio stations in Singapore]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Maltese government agencies to [[:Category:Government agencies of Malta]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
'''Malta Maritime Authority''' ('''MMA''', ''Awtorità Marittima ta' Malta'') used to be an independent [[state corporation]] and [[government agency]] that is responsible for the governance, operation, regulation and promotion of the [[port]]s of the Mediterranean [[archipelago]] nation of [[Malta]]. Operation of the principal cargo port, [[Malta Freeport]], is done in conjunction with Malta Freeport Terminals, a company established in 1988.<ref>[http://www.maltafreeport.com.mt/FPPages.asp?section=2&sub=1 Malta Freeport, Company profile]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Malta's smaller ports provide service to [[pleasure craft]] and [[yacht marina]]s, [[passenger ferry|ferry services]], the [[fishing industry]] and local trade. The MMA's Ports Directorate is the [[port authority]] for all ports in Malta.<ref>[http://www.mma.gov.mt/org_setup_ports.htm MMA, The Organization, Ports Directorate] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210001720/http://mma.gov.mt/org_setup_ports.htm |date=2009-02-10 }}</ref> The Malta International Ship Register is a department of the MMA.<ref>[http://www.mma.gov.mt/ship_registration_ship_registry.htm MMA, Ship Registration] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117161902/http://mma.gov.mt/ship_registration_ship_registry.htm |date=2009-01-17 }}</ref>
As from 2010 the MMA no longer exists as a separate entity but forms part of Transport Malta, a governmental institution which encompasses transport control of the islands over sea, land and air.
==Major ports== [[Malta]] has a rich maritime heritage, and principal ports include:<ref>[http://www.mma.gov.mt/ports_mainports.htm MMA, Port Notices, Ports] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203100312/http://mma.gov.mt/ports_mainports.htm |date=2009-02-03 }}</ref> *[[Malta Freeport]] at [[Marsaxlokk Harbour]] is the nation's principal [[cargo|cargo port]]. *[[Grand Harbour]] at [[Valletta]] is a cargo port that has been in operation since the times of the [[Roman Empire]]. *[[Marsamxett Harbour]] has pleasure boat [[marina]]s.
==See also== *[[Government of Malta]] *[[Port authority]] *[[Port operator]] *[[Transport in Malta#Ports and harbours|Transport in Malta]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mma.gov.mt/ Malta Maritime Authority official site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081006065619/http://www.maltafreeport.com.mt/default.asp Malta Freeport official site] *[http://www.gozochannel.com/ Gozo Channel Company, providing ferry services] *[http://www.tugmalta.com/ Tug Malta official site] *[http://www.imli.org/ International Maritime Law Institute, in Msida, Malta]
[[Category:Government agencies of Malta]] [[Category:Water transport in Malta]] [[Category:Port authorities]] [[Category:Ports and harbours of Malta]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1991]] [[Category:Ship registration]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Malta]]
{{Malta-stub}} {{Port-stub}}

{{Other uses|Melissa (disambiguation)}} {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox company | name = Melissa S.A.
''Μέλισσα Κίκιζας Α.Ε.'' | logo = Melissa_Kikizas_sign.png | type = [[private company|Private]] | company_slogan = | foundation = | location = [[Greece]] | key_people = | num_employees = | industry = | products = [[tomato sauce]], [[Spaghetti]] | revenue = | homepage = http://www.melissa.gr/en/ }} '''Melissa S.A.''' ({{lang-el|Μέλισσα}}) is a [[Greece|Greek]] [[tomato sauce]] company and is one of the major tomato sauce brands in the country. It is packaged with paper cartons and [[Tetra Brik]]. ==Logo== Its logo has a red oval facing left to right with white rims. It has its company name in the middle. ==Information== Its packaging colour is coloured green and features tomato sauce in the middle. ==See also== *[[Asteris]] *[[Kyknos S.A.]] *[[Pelargos]] *[[Sevath]] *[[List of companies in Greece]] [[Category:Food and drink companies of Greece]] {{Greece-stub}} {{Europe-company-stub}}

[[Maggie Badawi]] | director = [[Hany Tamba]] | released = {{Film date|2008|08|13|df=y}} | runtime = 98 minutes | country = Lebanon | music = [[Khaled Mouzanar]] | budget = | cinematography = [[Emmanuel Soyer]] | language = [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[French language|French]] | producer = [[Emmanuel Agneray]]
[[Jérôme Bleitrach]] | distributor = Haut et Court
Films Distributions }} '''''Melodrama Habibi''''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]:ميلودراما حبيبي, [[French language|French]]: Une chanson dans la tête), the first feature film by [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] director [[Hany Tamba]], is a 2008 [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[film]]. The film is set to be released on August 13, 2008 in France and Belgium.[http://www.hautetcourt.com/fiche.php?pkfilms=137 Haut et Court] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080902041514/http://www.hautetcourt.com/fiche.php?pkfilms=137 |date=2008-09-02 }} ==Synopsis== Jamil, a rich business man in Lebanon, decides to bring a once famous French singer, Bruno Caprice, to his wife's birthday (Randa). Bruno, who was known namely for one song "Quand tu t'en vas" in the 70's, accepts the invitation and goes to [[Beirut]]. But things get complicated when Randa is kidnapped, and Jamil decides that the show must go on. ==Cast and characters== *[[Julia Kassar]] as ''Randa Harfouche'' *[[Patrick Chesnais]] as ''Bruno Caprice'' *[[Pierrette Katrib]] as ''Nadine'' *[[Gabriel Yammine]] as ''Cézar'' *[[Lara Matar]] as ''Reem Harfouche'' and ''Randa'' when she was young *[[Pierre Chammassian]] as ''Jamil Harfouche'' *[[Maggie Badawi]] as ''Nadine'''s Mother *[[Majdi Machmouchi]] as ''Nadine'''s Father *[[Fadi Reaidy]] as the flight passenger and ''Madame Rose'' *[[Silina Choueiry]] as ''Roula'' (credited as Selina Choueiry) ==See also== *[[After Shave (short movie)|After Shave]] an award-winning short film by Hany Tamba. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|1=http://www.hautetcourt.com/fiche.php?pkfilms=137}} * {{IMDb title|1056434|Melodrama Habibi}} * [http://www.cineklik.com/ShowMovie.aspx?MovieID=1708 Showtimes in Lebanon] on Cineklik [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:Lebanese films]] [[Category:Arabic-language films]] {{Lebanon-film-stub}} {{2000s-comedy-drama-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Hatnote|Not to be confused with the [[Turoyo language]], also called Suryoyo.}} {{Infobox language |name=Mlaḥsô |nativename=ܡܠܚܬܝܐ ''Mlaḥsô'', ܣܘܪܝܝܐ ''Suryô'' |states=[[Turkey]], [[Syria]] |region=Originally two villages (Mlaḥsô/Yünlüce/Mela and ˁAnşa) near [[Lice, Turkey|Lice]] in [[Diyarbakır Province]] of southeastern [[Turkey]], later also [[Qamishli]] in northeastern [[Syria]]. |speakers= | extinct = 1998 | ref = e17 |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Semitic languages|Semitic]] |fam3=[[Central Semitic languages|Central Semitic]] |fam4=[[Northwest Semitic languages|Northwest Semitic]] |fam5=[[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] |fam6=[[Eastern Aramaic languages|Eastern Aramaic]] |fam7=[[Central Neo-Aramaic]] |iso3=lhs |glotto=mlah1239 |glottorefname=Mlahso }} '''Mlaḥsô''' or '''Mlahsö''' ({{lang-syc|ܡܠܚܬܝܐ}}), sometimes referred to as '''Suryoyo''' or '''Surayt''', is an extinct or dormant [[Central Neo-Aramaic|Central Neo-Aramaic language]]. It was traditionally spoken in eastern [[Turkey]] and later also in northeastern [[Syria]] by [[West Syrian Rite|Jacobite]] [[Assyrian people|Syriac-Assyrians]].{{cite journal|last=Jastrow|first=Otto|title=Mlaḥsô: An Unknown Neo-Aramaic Language of Turkey|journal=Journal of Semitic Studies|date=1985|volume=30|pages=265–270|doi=10.1093/jss/xxx.2.265}} The Mlaḥsô language (Surayt of Mlaḥsô) is closely related to the [[Turoyo language|Surayt of Turabdin]] but sufficiently different to be considered a separate language, with the syntax of the language having retained more features of [[Syriac language|Classical Syriac]] than Turoyo.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ethnologue.com/language/lhs|title=Mlahsö|work=Ethnologue|access-date=2017-05-14}} It was spoken in the villages of Mlaḥsô ({{lang-tr|Yünlüce}}, {{lang-ku|Mela}}), a village established by two monks from the [[Tur Abdin]] mountain range, and in the village of ˁAnşa near [[Lice, Turkey|Lice]], [[Diyarbakır]], [[Turkey]]. Aside from their native language, many Mlaḥsô speakers were fluent in [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Levantine Arabic|Arabic]], [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Kurmanji language|Kurdish]] and [[Zazaki language|Zaza]]. ==Etymology== The name of the village and the language is derived from the earlier Aramaic word ''mālaḥtā'', 'salt marsh'. The literary Syriac name for the language is ''Mlaḥthoyo''. The native speakers of Mlaḥsô referred to their language simply as ''Suryô'', or Syriac.Jastrow, Otto. 1997. "Der Neuaramaische Dialek von Mlahso." In British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies, reviewed by Geoffrey Khan. 299-300. British Society for Middle Eastern Studies. ==History and Distribution== The language was still spoken by a handful of people in the 1970s. The [[Last speaker of language|last fluent native speaker]] of Mlaḥsô, Ibrahim Ḥanna, died in 1998 in [[Qamishli]]. His daughters, Munira in Qamishlo, Shamiram in Lebanon, and son Dr. Isḥaq Ibrahim in Germany are the only speakers left with some limited native proficiency of the language. Recordings of Ibrahim Ḥanna speaking the language are available on [http://www.semarch.uni-hd.de/tondokumente.php43?LD_ID=4&RG_ID=9&ORT_ID=12&lang=en Heidelberg University's Semitic Sound Archive] which were done by Otto Jastrow, a prominent German semiticist who is credited as the modern "discoverer" of the language and published the first modern research papers on the existence of Mlaḥsô and its linguistic features. On 3 May 2009, a historical event in the history of the Mlaḥsô Surayt language took place. The [[Suroyo TV]] television station aired the program series ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uswfjcVLHBg Dore w yawmotho]'', which was about the village Mlaḥsô (and the Tur Abdin village Tamarze). Dr. Isḥaq Ibrahim, the son of Ibrahim Ḥanna, was a guest and spoke in the Mlaḥsô language with his sisters Shamiram in Lebanon and Munira in [[Qamishli]] live on the phone. Otto Jastrow was also interviewed regarding his expertise on Mlaḥsô. Turabdin [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]]/Syriacs viewers and those present at the show could for the first time ever in modern times hear the language live. The extinction of Mlaḥsô can be attributed to the small amount of original speakers of the language, and them being limited to two isolated villages, resulting in a disproportionate loss of speakers during the [[Assyrian genocide]] compared to Turoyo and other variants of Neo-Aramaic. ==Phonology== Mlahsô is phonologically less conservative than Turoyo. This is particularly noticeable in the use of ''s'' and ''z'' for classical ''θ'' and ''ð''. The classical ''v'' has been retained though, while it has collapsed into ''w'' in Turoyo. Also sometimes ''y'' ([[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] /j/) replaces ''ġ''. Mlaḥsô also renders the combination of vowel plus ''y'' as a single, fronted vowel rather than a [[diphthong]] or a glide. === Consonants === {|class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2| ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! colspan=3|[[Dental consonant|Dental]] ! colspan=3|[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Palato-alveolar consonant|Palato-alveolar]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Pharyngeal consonant|Pharyn-
geal]] ! rowspan=2 colspan=2|[[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! colspan=2|plain || colspan=2|[[pharyngealization|emphatic]] || colspan=2|plain |- align=center ! [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | style="border-right: 0;" | || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|m}} | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|n}} | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| |- align=center ! [[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|p}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|b}} | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|t}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|d}} | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|tˤ}} || style="border-left: 0;" | | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|k}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ɡ}} | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|q}} || style="border-left: 0;" | | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ʔ}} || style="border-left: 0;" | |- align=center ! [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|tʃ}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|dʒ}} | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| |- align=center ! [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|f}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|v}} | style="border-right: 0;" | || style="border-left: 0;" | | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|sˤ}} || style="border-left: 0;" | | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|s}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|z}} | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ʃ}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ʒ}} | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|x}} || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ɣ}} | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ħ}} || rowspan=2 style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|ʕ}} | style="border-right: 0;" | {{IPAlink|h}} || style="border-left: 0;" | |- align=center ! [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | style="border-right: 0;" | || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|w}} | colspan=6| {{IPAlink|l}} | colspan=2| | style="border-right: 0;" | || style="border-left: 0;" | {{IPAlink|j}} | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| |- align=center ! [[Trill consonant|Trill]] | colspan=2| | colspan=6| {{IPA|r}} | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| | colspan=2| |} === Vowels === Mlahsô has the following set of vowels: * [[Close front unrounded vowel]] – {{IPAslink|i}} * [[Close-mid front unrounded vowel]] – {{IPAslink|e}} * [[Open front unrounded vowel]] – {{IPAslink|a}} * [[Open back rounded vowel]] – {{IPAslink|ɒ}} * [[Close back rounded vowel]] – {{IPAslink|u}} == Morphology == Mlaḥsô is more [[conservative (language)|conservative]] than Turoyo in grammar and vocabulary, using classical Syriac words and constructions while also preserving the original Aramaic form.Kim, Ronald. 2008. "Stammbaum or Continuum? The Subgrouping of Modern Aramaic Dialects Reconsidered." In Journal of the American Oriental Society 128, no. 3, 505-531. ==Vocabulary== {| class="wikitable" |- ! English !! Mlaḥsô |- | '''''person''''' || nṓšo |- | '''''father''''' || avó |- | '''''paternal uncle''''' || dozó |- | '''''trouble''''' || renyó |- | '''''donkey''''' || ḥmṓrō |- | '''''one''''' || ḥā |- | '''''door''''' || tár'ṓ |- | '''''goat''''' || ḗzō |- | '''''great, big''''' || rābṓ |- | '''''house''''' || baytṓ |- | '''''ten''''' || 'esrṓ |- | '''''grapes''''' || 'envḗ |- | '''''mouth''''' || pēmṓ |- | '''''morning''''' || safrṓ |- | '''''three''''' || tlōsō |- | '''''sleep''''' || šensṓ |- | '''''hand''''' || īzṓ |- | '''''seven''''' || šav'ṓ |- | '''''today''''' || yōmā́n |- | '''''in, into''''' || lġāv |- | '''''brother''''' || āḥṓ |- | '''''why''''' || lmūn |- | '''''what'''''|| mūn |- | '''''much, many, very''''' || sāy |- | '''''town''''' || mzītṓ |- | '''''cock''''' || toġó |} === Example phrases === {| class="wikitable" |- ! English !! Mlaḥsô |- | They sleep || dōmxī́ |- | I wash || māsī́ġno |- | He loved || rhī́mle |- | She gave || hī́vla |- | I sold || zābḗnli |- | He demanded || tlī́ble |- | He stole || gnī́vle |- | His house || baytā́v |- | His place || duksā́v |- | From him || mēnā́v |} === Example sentences === {| class="wikitable" |- ! English !! Mlaḥsô |- | Where is my hen? || eyko-yo talġuntézi |} == See also == *[[Turoyo language|Surayt of Turabdin]] *[[Syriac language]] *[[Assyrian people]] ==References== {{reflist}} *Jastrow, Otto (1994). ''Der neuaramäische Dialekt von Mlaḥsô''. Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz. {{ISBN|3-447-03498-X}}. ==Further reading== * Goldenberg, Gideon. 2000. "Early Neo-Aramaic and Present-day Dialectical Diversity." In Journal of Semitic Studies XLV/1, 69-86. Jerusalem. * Hoberman, Robert D. 1988. "The History of the Modern Aramaic Pronouns and Pronominal Suffixes." In Journal of the American Oriental Society 108, no. 4, 557-575. American Oriental Society. *Jastrow, Otto. 1997. "16. The Neo-Aramaic Languages." In The Semitic Languages, edited by Robert Hetzron, 334–377. New York: Routledge. * Jastrow, Otto. 1996. "Passive Formation in Turoyo and Mlahso." In Israel Oriental Studies XVI: Studies in Modern Semitic Languages, edited by Shlomo Izre’el, 49–57. Leiden: Brill. * Jastrow, Otto. 1994. Der neuaramäische Dialekt von Mlaḥsô. Semitica Viva 14. Wiesbaden: Harrassowitz * Khan, Geoffrey. 1999. "The Neo-Aramaic Dialect Spoken by Jews from the Region of Arbel (Iraqi Kurdistan)." In Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London 62, no. 2, 213-225. * Khan, Geoffrey. 2003. "Some Remarks on Linguistic and Lexical Change in the North Eastern Neo-Aramaic Dialects." In Aramaic Studies 1, no. 2, 179-190. * Mutzafi, Hezy. 2006. "On the Etymology of Some Enigmatic Words in northeastern Neo-Aramaic." In Aramaic Studies 4, no. 1, 83-99. ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uswfjcVLHBg Suroyo TV 2009-05-03 Dore w yawmotho - Mlaḥso & Tamarze] * [http://semarch.uni-hd.de/dokumentgruppen.php4?ST_ID=5&DT_ID=32 Semitisches Tonarchiv: Dokumentgruppe "Aramäisch/Mlahsô" (text in German)] * [http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/9229 Endangered Languages Project - Mlahso ] {{Neo-Aramaic}} {{Syriacs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mlahso Language}} [[Category:Eastern Aramaic languages]] [[Category:Neo-Aramaic languages]] [[Category:Languages of Asia]] [[Category:Languages of Syria]] [[Category:Languages of Turkey]] [[Category:Endangered Afroasiatic languages]]

[http://www.radio2.nl/playlist Playlist] | website = [http://www.radio2.nl www.radio2.nl] |city=|coordinates=|slogan=''Er is maar één NPO Radio 2''}} [[File:Radio 2 Logo.svg|thumb|200px|Radio 2 logo used until 2014.]] '''NPO Radio 2''' is a [[public broadcasting|public-service]] [[radio]] station from the [[Netherlands]], broadcasting in an [[adult hits]] format, focusing on the 1980s and 1990s, however 1960s and 1970s hits may also air. It is part of the [[Netherlands Public Broadcasting]] system, NPO. The latest statistics show that Radio 2 has got a higher market share than any other station: 12%.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediacourant.nl/2018/07/npo-radio-2-houdt-radio-538-van-koppositie-af/|title=NPO Radio 2 houdt Radio 538 van koppositie af – Mediacourant.nl|website=www.mediacourant.nl|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-19}} ==History== The origins of the station go back to "'''Hilversum 1'''", launched in 1947. The name change to "Radio 2" took place in 1985. In 2014, the name was changed to "NPO Radio 2". ==Target audience and content== The primary target adult audience comprises listeners aged between 35 and 54, while [[NPO 3FM]] is aimed at listeners aged 15-34. The station plays a wide variety of songs from the 1980s to 1990s, though 1960s and 1970s songs may also be incorporated. Current hits air occasionally and are based upon 3FM's Mega Top 50 chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/Radio2nl?sk=info |title=Radio 2 - De muziek zegt alles - Hilversum - Radio-, tv- en mediaproductie - Info |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2014-05-18}} NPO Radio 2 is also known for its annual [[Top 2000|Radio 2 Top 2000]] presentation, broadcast since 1999 continuously from [[Christmas Day]] till [[New Year's Day]] 0:00 CET "the 2000 best songs ever made" voted by the listeners.{{cite web|url=http://www.radiofreak.nl/nieuws/12105/Radio-2-presenteert-Top-2000-dj-elftal/ |title=Radio 2 presenteert Top 2000 dj-elftal |publisher=RadioFreak.nl |date=2012-12-01 |accessdate=2014-05-18}} ==Content contributors== As of 2018, the following broadcasting organizations participate in the production of NPO Radio 2's programming: *[[AVROTROS]] *[[BNNVARA]] *[[Evangelische Omroep|EO]] *[[KRO-NCRV]] *[[VPRO]] *[[Wakker Nederland|WNL]] ==DJs== {{Div col begin}} * Marc Adriani * Leo Blokhuis * Cobus Bosscha * Peter van Bruggen * [[Daniël Dekker]] * Edwin Diergaarde * Wouter van der Goes * Sander Guis * Bert Haandrikman * Sander de Heer * [[Dolf Jansen]] * Astrid de Jong * Ron Kas * Corné Klijn * Jeanne Kooijmans * Bert Kranenbarg * Sara Kroos * Felix Meurders * Frank du Mosch * Jan-Willem Roodbeen * Frits Sissing * [[Mart Smeets]] * Frits Spits * Marc Stakenburg * [[Rob Stenders]] * Gijs Staverman * Stefan Stasse * Henk van Steeg * Jeroen Kijk in de Vegte * Alfred van de Wege * [[Ruud de Wild]] {{Div col end}} == Slogans == * ''De warmste zender van Nederland'' (The warmest channel in the Netherlands) (1992-1995) * ''Je voelt je thuis'' (You're feeling at home) (1995-2001, this slogan is now used by [[NPO Radio 5|Radio 5]]) * ''Je hoort nog eens wat'' (You hear something again) (2001-2008) * ''Radio 2 is overal'' (Radio 2 is everywhere) (2008-2011) * ''De muziek zegt alles'' (The music is everything) (2011-2013) * Come Together (2013-2015) * ''De muziek is AAN'' (The music is ON) (2015-now) * ''De beste popmuziek ooit gemaakt'' (The best pop music ever made) (2017-now) ==See also== * [[List of radio stations in the Netherlands]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|NPO Radio 2}} *{{Official website|http://www.radio2.nl/ }} {{Radio stations in the Netherlands}} {{NPO}} {{coord missing|Netherlands}} revision.text:
{{Other uses|Paris Protocol (disambiguation){{!}}Paris Protocol}}
On 28 August 1952 the then [[NATO member states]] signed the '''Paris Protocol ''' in [[Paris]]. Its official title is "On the Status of International Military Headquarters Set up Pursuant to the North Atlantic Treaty" and it establishes the status of allied and national headquarters and respective procedures. The Protocol is part of the so-called NATO legal acquis.
All NATO member states have ratified the protocol, except Canada, which signed but did not ratify it. France ratified the protocol in 1955 but denounced its ratification in 1966.
== See also == * [[Headquarter Protocol]]
== External links == *[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/official_texts_17300.htm Text of the treaty] *[https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/85631.pdf Treaty ratifications].

revision.text:
'''Postajankt-iki''' ("the fast old man") is the youngest son of the god [[Num-Torum]] in [[Ugric peoples|Ob-Ugrian]] mythology. He has several other names: '''Sorni-iki''' ("the golden old man"), and '''Õi-shlapt-lah-hliotõ-iki''' (which is used if one wishes to prevent him from being frightened during an offering). He rides upon a white horse. Postajankt-iki is easily started when someone calls his name (even jumping into the air), but it is not wise to call him for no reason because then woe befalls that person, according to the myths.
==External links and references== *[http://haldjas.folklore.ee/~anzori/HANT2ENG.HTM World view of the Hanti]
[[Category:Ob-Ugrian gods]]
{{Siberia-myth-stub}}

{{Advert|article|date=April 2014}}
{{Infobox software | name = Runkeeper | title = Runkeeper | logo = Corporate_logo_of_Runkeeper_(FitnessKeeper,_Inc.).png | logo size = 300px | logo caption = | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | author = | developer = FitnessKeeper | released = {{Start date and age|2008}} | discontinued = | latest release version = 4.3.1<ref name="applestore">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/runkeeper-gps-track-running/id300235330?mt=8&ign-mpt=uo%3D4 |title=Runkeeper - GPS Track Running Walking Cycling on the App Store on iTunes |publisher=iTunes |date= |accessdate=2014-03-04}}</ref> | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | frequently updated = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | status = | programming language = | operating system = [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | platform = | size = Varies with device | language = English, Spanish, French, German, Italian, Brazilian, Portuguese, Japanese and Russian<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2013/03/27/runkeeper-moves-beyond-english-with-6-new-languages-including-french-spanish-and-japanese/ |author=Paul Sawers|title=RunKeeper moves beyond English with 6 new languages, including French, Spanish and Japanese |publisher=thenextweb |date=2013-03-27 |accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> | language count = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | language footnote = | genre = [[Physical fitness|Fitness]] | license = [[Proprietary (software)|Proprietary]] | alexa = | website = {{URL|http://runkeeper.com}} | standard = | AsOf = }} '''Runkeeper''' is a [[GPS]] fitness-tracking [[Mobile app|app]] for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] with over 50 million users.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2015/11/the-technology-that-created-a-new-generation-of-runners/417126/|title=The Technology That Created a New Generation of Runners|last=|first=|website=|accessdate=2017-01-06}}</ref> It was launched in 2008 by CEO Jason Jacobs with the help of "moonlighting engineers"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.raizlabs.com/blog/work/runkeeper/|title=RunKeeper: Product and app development by Raizlabs|last=|first=|date=2011-01-01|website=|publisher=Raizlabs|accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> and Raizlabs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.raizlabs.com/blog/work/runkeeper/|title=RunKeeper - App Developer|newspaper=Raizlabs|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-14}}</ref> In late 2011, Runkeeper secured $10 million in a Series B financing, led by Spark Capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/03/02/founder-stories-runkeeper-striving-to-becoming-the-facebook-for-health/|title=(Founder Stories) Runkeeper: Striving To Becoming The Facebook For Health |publisher=Techcrunch |date=2012-03-02 |accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref> In February 2016, Runkeeper was acquired by [[ASICS]].
== Functions == Runkeeper allows users to track fitness activities (such as [[walking]], [[running]] and [[cycling]]) using GPS<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kvue.com/news/consumer/Best-free-apps-182063191.html|title=Best free apps - kvue.com Austin|publisher=kvue.com Austin|author=Shannon Powell Hart|date=2012-12-04|accessdate=2013-11-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202224810/http://www.kvue.com/news/consumer/Best-free-apps-182063191.html|archivedate=2013-12-02|df=}}</ref> and allows users see detailed statistics around their pace, distance, and time. Runkeeper tracks statistics, progress, and applies coaching, with built-in audio cues. Users can listen and control music while working out, measure their heart rate, and take pictures while engaged in an activity.<ref name='applestore' />
The application tracks performance over time, allowing users to view a detailed history of activities, get notifications for new personal "bests" and milestones, measure progress against current goals, follow detailed plans, and turn any activity into a route to do again later using built-in GPS.<ref name="applestore"/> Runkeeper allows users to share their personal content with friends through posting to Facebook and Twitter, and allows supporters watch live maps of workouts and races as users run.<ref name="applestore"/> The application has released an open API for outside developers to plug into Runkeeper users’ feeds.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/playbook/2011/06/runkeeper-facebook-of-fitness/|title=How RunKeeper Could Become the Facebook of Fitness|publisher=wired.com|author=Erik Malinowski |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2013-11-26}}</ref>
Runkeeper periodically comes up with 'challenges' which rewards the user for completing certain criteria in a certain time-frame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://runkeeper.com/challenge|title=Runkeeper Challenges - Runkeeper}}</ref> The first challenge was in May 2014 with the goal of completing and GPS tracking a 5 kilometers between May 19 and June 19 to be entered in winning an [[LG]] Lifeband.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://runkeeper.com/challenge/lg|title=LG Lifeband 5K Challenge - Runkeeper}}</ref>
== Criticism and controversy == In May 2016, the Runkeeper software came to the attention of the Norwegian Consumer Council for breaching European data protection laws. It is alleged to continue tracking user's locations after the application is terminated and to share this information with advertisers in ways that exceed the bounds of the application's terms and conditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.androidauthority.com/runkeeper-user-location-tracking-data-advertisers-692346/|title=Runkeeper is secretly tracking you around the clock and sending your data to advertisers|date=13 May 2016|website=Android Authority|publisher=Android Authority|quote="The NCC's investigation into Runkeeper discovered that user location data is tracked around the clock and gets transmitted to a third party advertiser in the U.S. called Kiip.me."|last1=Carlon|first1=Kris|accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Endomondo]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://runkeeper.com * https://blog.bounts.it/2014/runkeeper/
